newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - Copper rally shrugs off Sumitomo blues.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Copper rally shrugs off Sumitomo blues.

text.p: Prospects that China may buy copper for its strategic stockpile helped drive the price to its highest since the Sumitomo Corp scandal last June on Wednesday.
Traders also cited technical factors in the brisk rally by the London Metal Exchange (LME) flagship copper contract.
It rose sharply in early trading as speculative buy-stops and waves of short covering were triggered after it broke above the earlier 1997 high of $2,313 a tonne.
Three months delivery copper raced to an 8-1/2 month peak of $2,360 for a gain of almost $75 from Tuesday afternoon. It eased on profit-taking but closed the afternoon London session firm at $2,340.
Traders said the move up was made against a backdrop of renewed nearby tightness and expectations that China might buy copper to replenish strategic stocks.
"There is some concern that there will be a rush of Chinese demand..." said brokerage GNI Ltd.
Values are the strongest since the throes of a price collapse that accompanied the dismissal by Japan's Sumitomo Corp of its star copper trader, Yasuo Hamanaka.
Hamanaka, on trial in Tokyo for forgery and fraud, was alleged by the Japanese firm to have lost it $2.6 billion in maverick trades.

He had been the mastermind of the world trade in copper. A hoard of stocks that he controlled kept prices high and his exit triggered a collapse from around $2,700 per tonne. "It's very tight moving into the peak demand period of March-June," said analyst Robin Bahr of brokers Brandeis in a comment on the present rebound.

"A rising market creates fear. People will buy because they don't want to miss the boat. You tend to get restocking..." he added. Copper's surge fuelled parallel rallies in nearly all of the other base metals. Aluminium matched the gains in copper and moved to end the day above resistance at $1,600 a tonne.
Elsewhere in commodity markets, coffee prices were again under pressure as selling continued to hit a rally that had taken them up by around 50 percent in a few weeks.
Speculative liquidation was renewed on the London market for Robusta grades of coffee beans after further weakness in the Arabica futures that are traded in New York on Tuesday.
London May futures for the lower quality Robustas had hit $1,705 per tonne on Friday. On Wednesday they dropped as low at $1,460 before edging up slightly towards the close.

Gold continued to firm to a London afternoon fixing of $346.25 per ounce, recovering in subdued activity from recent 3-3/4 year lows. Most other commodities were little changed with crude oil just firmer.
